questionText: What is the key concept introduced in the study of the motion of extended bodies?
explanation: The centre of mass is a crucial concept when discussing the motion of extended bodies.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is a rigid body defined in the context of this chapter?

options.text: A body that can change shape under force
A body with a perfectly definite and unchanging shape

explanation: A rigid body is defined as a body with a perfectly definite and unchanging shape.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the main inadequacy of the idealised model of a particle when dealing with the motion of extended bodies?

options.text: It ignores the finite size of real bodies
It does not account for point masses

explanation: The idealised model of a particle is inadequate because it ignores the finite size of real bodies.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: In the context of rigid bodies, what is meant by 'pure translational motion'?

options.text: All particles have the same velocity
All particles rotate around a fixed point

explanation: In pure translational motion, all particles of the body have the same velocity.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which of the following is an example of a rigid body?
explanation: A steel beam is considered a rigid body because it has a definite shape that does not change significantly under normal conditions.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which example illustrates the inadequacy of the particle model for describing motion?
explanation: A rolling cylinder illustrates the inadequacy of the particle model because it involves both translational and rotational motion.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What kind of motion does a ceiling fan exhibit?

options.text: Combination of translational and rotational motion

explanation: A ceiling fan exhibits pure rotational motion around a fixed axis.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Why is no real body considered truly rigid?

options.text: Because real bodies have finite size
Because real bodies deform under the influence of forces

explanation: No real body is truly rigid because all real bodies deform to some extent under the influence of forces.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to a rigid body when it is fixed along a straight line?
explanation: When a rigid body is fixed along a straight line, it can only rotate about that axis.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which of the following best describes the motion of a rolling cylinder down an inclined plane?

options.text: Combination of translational and rotational motion

explanation: The motion of a rolling cylinder down an inclined plane is a combination of translational and rotational motion.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What kind of motion can a rigid body have if it is not constrained in any way?

options.text: Combination of translational and rotational motion

explanation: A rigid body that is not constrained can have a combination of translational and rotational motion.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Why can a potter’s wheel be considered an example of rotational motion?

options.text: Because it rotates around a fixed axis

explanation: A potter’s wheel is an example of rotational motion because it rotates around a fixed axis.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: In the context of rotational motion, what is meant by the term 'axis of rotation'?

options.text: The line about which a body translates
The line along which a body deforms
The fixed line about which a body rotates
The point around which a body remains stationary

explanation: The 'axis of rotation' is the fixed line about which a body rotates.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which of the following is a characteristic of a rigid body in pure translational motion?

options.text: All particles have the same velocity
The body rotates around an axis

explanation: In pure translational motion, all particles of a rigid body have the same velocity.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which type of motion involves all particles of the body moving together with the same velocity?
explanation: In pure translational motion, all particles of the body move together with the same velocity.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the centre of mass of a system of particles?

options.text: The point where the mass of the system is concentrated
The point where the system's velocity is zero
The geometric centre of the system
The point where all forces balance

explanation: The centre of mass is the point where the mass of the system can be considered to be concentrated for the purpose of analyzing motion.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: For a system of two particles with masses m1 and m2 located at x1 and x2 respectively, how is the position of the centre of mass (X) calculated?
explanation: The position of the centre of mass for two particles is calculated using the formula $X = \frac{m_1x_1 + m_2x_2}{m_1 + m_2}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the position of the centre of mass for two particles of equal mass?

options.text: Exactly midway between the two particles
Closer to the particle with higher mass
At the position of one of the particles

explanation: For two particles of equal mass, the centre of mass lies exactly midway between them.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: For a system of three particles with masses m1, m2, and m3 at positions (x1, y1), (x2, y2), and (x3, y3), what are the coordinates of the centre of mass?
explanation: The coordinates of the centre of mass for three particles are given by $(X, Y) = \left(\frac{m_1x_1 + m_2x_2 + m_3x_3}{m_1 + m_2 + m_3}, \frac{m_1y_1 + m_2y_2 + m_3y_3}{m_1 + m_2 + m_3}\right)$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the centre of mass for a uniform thin rod of length L?
explanation: For a uniform thin rod, the centre of mass is located at its geometric center.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the centre of mass calculated for a continuous distribution of mass?

options.text: By integrating the mass elements over the entire body
By summing the positions of all particles
By averaging the coordinates of all particles
By finding the midpoint of the body

explanation: For a continuous distribution of mass, the centre of mass is calculated by integrating the mass elements over the entire body.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which of the following bodies has its centre of mass coinciding with its geometric centre?
explanation: A homogeneous sphere has its centre of mass coinciding with its geometric centre due to its uniform mass distribution.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Where is the centre of mass located for a triangular lamina?

options.text: At the centroid of the triangle
At the midpoint of any side

explanation: The centre of mass of a triangular lamina is located at the centroid of the triangle.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: If a system consists of particles with different masses, where does the centre of mass lie?
explanation: The centre of mass lies closer to the heavier particles in a system with different masses.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: In the equation for the centre of mass, what does the symbol ∑ (sigma) denote?
explanation: The symbol ∑ (sigma) denotes summation in the equation for the centre of mass.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the centre of mass of a system of particles affected if the origin of the coordinate system is chosen at the centre of mass?

options.text: The coordinates of the centre of mass are zero
The mass of the system changes

explanation: If the origin of the coordinate system is chosen at the centre of mass, the coordinates of the centre of mass are zero.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the centre of mass of a body if it is considered as a continuous distribution of mass?

options.text: It is found by averaging the coordinates
It is located at the midpoint

explanation: For a continuous distribution of mass, the centre of mass is calculated using integrals.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the significance of the centre of mass in understanding the motion of extended bodies?

options.text: It simplifies the analysis by reducing the problem to the motion of a single point
It helps in calculating the weight of the body
It determines the shape of the body
It affects the internal structure of the body

explanation: The centre of mass simplifies the analysis by reducing the problem to the motion of a single point.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How do you find the centre of mass for a non-uniform rod?

options.text: By integrating over the mass distribution
By averaging the coordinates of its ends
By considering it as a uniform rod

explanation: For a non-uniform rod, the centre of mass is found by integrating over the mass distribution.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which point of a body remains stationary while it rotates about a fixed axis?

options.text: The point on the axis of rotation
The farthest point from the axis

explanation: The point on the axis of rotation remains stationary while the body rotates about a fixed axis.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the location of the centre of mass for a uniform circular ring?

options.text: At any point on the ring
At the midpoint of any diameter

explanation: For a uniform circular ring, the centre of mass is located at its geometric center.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the centre of mass of a system of n particles located?

options.text: By finding the weighted mean position of all particles
By averaging the masses of the particles
By calculating the total volume of the system
By locating the midpoint of the system

explanation: The centre of mass of a system of n particles is located by finding the weighted mean position of all particles.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the relation between the centre of mass and external forces acting on a system of particles?

options.text: The centre of mass moves as if all the mass and external forces are concentrated at that point
The centre of mass remains unaffected by external forces
The centre of mass only moves due to internal forces
The centre of mass moves independently of external forces

explanation: The centre of mass moves as if all the mass and external forces are concentrated at that point.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the significance of the centre of mass in rotational motion?

options.text: It helps in analyzing the rotational dynamics of a body
It determines the color of the body

explanation: The centre of mass is significant in rotational motion as it helps in analyzing the rotational dynamics of a body.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the position of the centre of mass for a three-dimensional body calculated?

options.text: By considering the coordinates of the mass elements in all three dimensions
By averaging the positions of the particles in one dimension
By summing the masses of the particles

explanation: For a three-dimensional body, the position of the centre of mass is calculated by considering the coordinates of the mass elements in all three dimensions.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the centre of mass of a system when the masses of the particles are equal?

options.text: It is located at the geometric center
It is closer to one of the particles

explanation: When the masses of the particles in a system are equal, the centre of mass is located at the geometric center.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which of the following points on a body can be considered as the centre of mass?

options.text: Any point where the body's mass is effectively concentrated
Any arbitrary point on the body
A point on the surface of the body

explanation: The centre of mass is any point where the body's mass is effectively concentrated for the purpose of analysis.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the effect of the position of the centre of mass on the stability of a body?

options.text: A lower centre of mass increases stability
A higher centre of mass increases stability
The position of the centre of mass has no effect on stability
The centre of mass affects only the weight of the body

explanation: A lower centre of mass increases the stability of a body, making it less likely to tip over.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the centre of mass of a lamina different from that of a solid body?

options.text: The centre of mass of a lamina is calculated in two dimensions
The centre of mass of a lamina does not exist
The centre of mass of a solid body is calculated in two dimensions

explanation: The centre of mass of a lamina is calculated in two dimensions, whereas that of a solid body is calculated in three dimensions.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the centre of mass when the configuration of a system of particles changes?

options.text: The position of the centre of mass changes
The position of the centre of mass remains the same
The total mass of the system changes
The centre of mass becomes undefined

explanation: The position of the centre of mass changes when the configuration of a system of particles changes.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the effect of an external force applied at the centre of mass?

options.text: It does not affect the body
It increases the mass of the body

explanation: An external force applied at the centre of mass causes translational motion of the body.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Where is the centre of mass located for a homogeneous cube?

options.text: At the midpoint of any edge

explanation: For a homogeneous cube, the centre of mass is located at its geometric center.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: In the context of the centre of mass, what is meant by 'weighted mean position'?

options.text: The position averaged over the masses of the particles

explanation: The 'weighted mean position' refers to the position averaged over the masses of the particles.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the significance of the centre of mass in a system of particles?

options.text: It represents the average position of all the particles
It is the point where the system's velocity is zero
It determines the shape of the system
It affects the color of the system

explanation: The centre of mass represents the average position of all the particles in a system.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the concept of the centre of mass simplify the study of the motion of extended bodies?

options.text: It reduces the problem to the motion of a single point
It makes the calculations more complex
It does not affect the study

explanation: The concept of the centre of mass simplifies the study of the motion of extended bodies by reducing the problem to the motion of a single point.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the centre of mass of a system if an external force acts on the system?

options.text: The centre of mass moves in the direction of the force
The centre of mass remains stationary
The centre of mass moves opposite to the force
The centre of mass is unaffected

explanation: If an external force acts on a system, the centre of mass moves in the direction of the force.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the centre of mass of a system of particles influenced by internal forces?

options.text: Internal forces do not affect the centre of mass
Internal forces move the centre of mass
Internal forces cause the centre of mass to rotate
Internal forces increase the mass of the system

explanation: Internal forces do not affect the centre of mass of a system of particles.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the centre of mass of a system with uniform mass distribution?
explanation: For a system with uniform mass distribution, the centre of mass is the geometric center.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which factor determines the location of the centre of mass in a system of particles?

options.text: The mass and position of each particle

explanation: The location of the centre of mass in a system of particles is determined by the mass and position of each particle.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the mass distribution of a body affect its centre of mass?

options.text: The centre of mass shifts towards the heavier parts
The centre of mass is unaffected by mass distribution
The centre of mass always lies at the geometric center
The centre of mass shifts towards the lighter parts

explanation: The centre of mass shifts towards the heavier parts of a body, depending on its mass distribution.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: In a system of particles, how does the position of the centre of mass change if one particle is moved?

options.text: The centre of mass shifts towards the new position of the particle
The centre of mass remains the same
The centre of mass moves in the opposite direction
The centre of mass becomes undefined

explanation: In a system of particles, the centre of mass shifts towards the new position of the moved particle.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which of the following describes the motion of the centre of mass in a closed system with no external forces?

options.text: The centre of mass moves with constant velocity
The centre of mass remains stationary

explanation: In a closed system with no external forces, the centre of mass moves with constant velocity.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the effect of gravitational force on the centre of mass of a body?

options.text: Gravitational force acts as if it is concentrated at the centre of mass
Gravitational force has no effect on the centre of mass
Gravitational force acts at the geometric center
Gravitational force acts at the surface of the body

explanation: Gravitational force acts as if it is concentrated at the centre of mass of the body.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the location of the centre of mass for a uniform solid sphere?

options.text: At the midpoint of a radius

explanation: For a uniform solid sphere, the centre of mass is located at its geometric center.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What determines the motion of the centre of mass in a system with internal interactions?

options.text: The net external forces acting on the system
The internal forces within the system

explanation: The motion of the centre of mass in a system with internal interactions is determined by the net external forces acting on the system.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the centre of mass if the configuration of a system of particles is symmetric?

options.text: The centre of mass coincides with the geometric center
The centre of mass shifts to one side
The centre of mass becomes undefined
The centre of mass lies outside the system

explanation: If the configuration of a system of particles is symmetric, the centre of mass coincides with the geometric center.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the motion of the centre of mass of a system when no external forces act on the system?

options.text: The centre of mass moves with constant velocity
The centre of mass remains stationary

explanation: When no external forces act on a system, the centre of mass moves with constant velocity.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: In a system of particles, what determines the motion of the centre of mass?

options.text: The net external forces acting on the system
The internal forces within the system

explanation: The motion of the centre of mass is determined by the net external forces acting on the system.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the velocity of the centre of mass relate to the velocities of the individual particles in a system?

options.text: The velocity of the centre of mass is the mass-weighted average of the velocities of the particles
The velocity of the centre of mass is the arithmetic average of the velocities of the particles
The velocity of the centre of mass is the geometric average of the velocities of the particles
The velocity of the centre of mass is the harmonic average of the velocities of the particles

explanation: The velocity of the centre of mass is the mass-weighted average of the velocities of the particles.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the motion of the centre of mass if the internal forces in a system are balanced?

options.text: The centre of mass continues to move with constant velocity
The centre of mass remains stationary

explanation: If the internal forces in a system are balanced, the centre of mass continues to move with constant velocity.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the acceleration of the centre of mass relate to the net external force acting on the system?

options.text: The acceleration of the centre of mass is directly proportional to the net external force
The acceleration of the centre of mass is inversely proportional to the net external force
The acceleration of the centre of mass is independent of the net external force
The acceleration of the centre of mass is equal to the net external force

explanation: The acceleration of the centre of mass is directly proportional to the net external force acting on the system.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the equation for the motion of the centre of mass under the influence of external forces?
explanation: The equation for the motion of the centre of mass under the influence of external forces is $M \frac{d^2\vec{R}}{dt^2} = \vec{F}_{ext}$, where $M$ is the total mass and $\vec{R}$ is the position of the centre of mass.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: In the absence of external forces, what type of motion does the centre of mass exhibit?
explanation: In the absence of external forces, the centre of mass exhibits uniform motion.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the position vector of the centre of mass of a system of particles calculated?
explanation: The position vector of the centre of mass of a system of particles is calculated using $\vec{R} = \frac{1}{M} \sum m_i \vec{r}_i$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the velocity of the centre of mass when external forces are applied?

options.text: The velocity of the centre of mass changes
The velocity of the centre of mass remains constant
The velocity of the centre of mass becomes zero
The velocity of the centre of mass oscillates

explanation: When external forces are applied, the velocity of the centre of mass changes according to the net external forces.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the role of the centre of mass in the motion of a system of particles?

options.text: It acts as a reference point for analyzing the motion of the system
It determines the shape of the system
It affects the internal forces of the system
It remains stationary in all cases

explanation: The centre of mass acts as a reference point for analyzing the motion of the system.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the internal interaction of particles affect the motion of the centre of mass?

options.text: Internal interactions do not affect the motion of the centre of mass
Internal interactions cause the centre of mass to accelerate
Internal interactions change the direction of the centre of mass
Internal interactions stop the motion of the centre of mass

explanation: Internal interactions do not affect the motion of the centre of mass; only external forces can change its motion.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the significance of the centre of mass in a collision between two bodies?

options.text: The centre of mass continues to move with constant velocity before and after the collision
The centre of mass comes to rest
The centre of mass moves in random directions

explanation: In a collision between two bodies, the centre of mass continues to move with constant velocity before and after the collision.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the acceleration of the centre of mass calculated in terms of external forces and total mass?
explanation: The acceleration of the centre of mass is calculated using $\vec{a} = \frac{\vec{F}_{ext}}{M}$, where $\vec{F}_{ext}$ is the net external force and $M$ is the total mass.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the motion of the centre of mass in a system with varying external forces?

options.text: The centre of mass accelerates or decelerates based on the net external force
The centre of mass moves with constant velocity
The centre of mass remains stationary

explanation: In a system with varying external forces, the centre of mass accelerates or decelerates based on the net external force.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the centre of mass behave in a system with no external forces but with internal forces present?

options.text: The centre of mass moves with constant velocity

explanation: In a system with no external forces, the centre of mass moves with constant velocity regardless of internal forces.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the role of the centre of mass in analyzing the motion of a rigid body?

options.text: It simplifies the analysis by considering the motion of a single point
It is irrelevant to the analysis
It affects only the rotational motion

explanation: The centre of mass simplifies the analysis of the motion of a rigid body by considering the motion of a single point.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the motion of the centre of mass affected in an isolated system with internal forces?

options.text: The motion of the centre of mass remains unaffected by internal forces
The motion of the centre of mass is altered by internal forces
The centre of mass stops moving
The centre of mass accelerates due to internal forces

explanation: In an isolated system with internal forces, the motion of the centre of mass remains unaffected by internal forces.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the centre of mass of a system if the external force is zero?

options.text: The centre of mass continues to move with constant velocity
The centre of mass remains stationary

explanation: If the external force is zero, the centre of mass continues to move with constant velocity.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: Which force is responsible for changing the motion of the centre of mass?
explanation: The motion of the centre of mass is changed by external forces.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the significance of the centre of mass in a two-body collision?

options.text: The centre of mass continues to move with the same velocity before and after the collision
The centre of mass comes to rest
The centre of mass changes its direction randomly

explanation: In a two-body collision, the centre of mass continues to move with the same velocity before and after the collision.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the presence of friction affect the motion of the centre of mass?

options.text: Friction causes the centre of mass to decelerate
Friction has no effect on the centre of mass
Friction causes the centre of mass to accelerate
Friction stops the motion of the centre of mass

explanation: The presence of friction causes the centre of mass to decelerate.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the centre of mass in a system with symmetrical mass distribution?

options.text: The centre of mass is at the geometric center
The centre of mass is at one of the vertices
The centre of mass is at the midpoint of one side
The centre of mass is outside the system

explanation: In a system with symmetrical mass distribution, the centre of mass is at the geometric center.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the centre of mass move in a system where internal forces are greater than external forces?

options.text: Internal forces do not affect the motion of the centre of mass

explanation: Internal forces do not affect the motion of the centre of mass; only external forces do.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the centre of mass in a rotating system of particles?

options.text: The centre of mass follows a circular path
The centre of mass remains stationary
The centre of mass accelerates linearly

explanation: In a rotating system of particles, the centre of mass follows a circular path.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the role of external torque in the motion of the centre of mass?

options.text: External torque does not affect the motion of the centre of mass
External torque changes the velocity of the centre of mass
External torque causes the centre of mass to accelerate
External torque stops the motion of the centre of mass

explanation: External torque does not affect the motion of the centre of mass; only external forces do.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the kinetic energy of a system related to the motion of its centre of mass?

options.text: The kinetic energy is the sum of the kinetic energies of the centre of mass and the particles
The kinetic energy is only due to the centre of mass
The kinetic energy is only due to the particles
The kinetic energy is independent of the centre of mass

explanation: The kinetic energy of a system is the sum of the kinetic energies of the centre of mass and the particles.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What happens to the centre of mass when the configuration of a system changes?

options.text: The position of the centre of mass changes
The position of the centre of mass remains the same

explanation: When the configuration of a system changes, the position of the centre of mass changes.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the centre of mass of a system with non-uniform mass distribution calculated?

options.text: By integrating the mass elements over the volume of the system
By averaging the coordinates of the particles
By summing the masses of the particles
By finding the midpoint of the system

explanation: The centre of mass of a system with non-uniform mass distribution is calculated by integrating the mass elements over the volume of the system.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the effect of an external impulse on the centre of mass?

options.text: The external impulse changes the momentum of the centre of mass
The external impulse has no effect on the centre of mass
The external impulse stops the motion of the centre of mass
The external impulse changes the shape of the centre of mass

explanation: An external impulse changes the momentum of the centre of mass.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the distribution of mass affect the position of the centre of mass in a system?

options.text: The centre of mass shifts towards the denser regions
The centre of mass remains at the geometric center
The centre of mass shifts towards the less dense regions
The centre of mass is unaffected by the distribution of mass

explanation: The position of the centre of mass shifts towards the denser regions of the system.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the centre of mass behave in a non-inertial frame of reference?

options.text: The centre of mass experiences fictitious forces
The centre of mass remains unaffected
The centre of mass moves with constant velocity
The centre of mass stops moving

explanation: In a non-inertial frame of reference, the centre of mass experiences fictitious forces.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the relation between the total momentum of a system and the motion of its centre of mass?

options.text: The total momentum is equal to the product of the total mass and the velocity of the centre of mass
The total momentum is equal to the sum of the individual momenta
The total momentum is independent of the centre of mass

explanation: The total momentum of a system is equal to the product of the total mass and the velocity of the centre of mass.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How is the centre of mass of a system affected by the application of an external force?

options.text: The centre of mass accelerates in the direction of the force
The centre of mass remains stationary
The centre of mass moves opposite to the force

explanation: The centre of mass accelerates in the direction of the external force.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the effect of gravity on the centre of mass of a free-falling body?

options.text: The centre of mass accelerates downward with acceleration $g$
The centre of mass remains stationary
The centre of mass accelerates upward
The centre of mass moves horizontally

explanation: The centre of mass of a free-falling body accelerates downward with acceleration $g$ due to gravity.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: How does the motion of the centre of mass differ in elastic and inelastic collisions?

options.text: The centre of mass moves with constant velocity in both cases
The centre of mass accelerates in elastic collisions
The centre of mass decelerates in inelastic collisions
The centre of mass remains stationary in inelastic collisions

explanation: In both elastic and inelastic collisions, the centre of mass moves with constant velocity.

questionText: How is the vector product of two vectors $\vec{A} = A_x \hat{i} + A_y \hat{j} + A_z \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = B_x \hat{i} + B_y \hat{j} + B_z \hat{k}$ calculated?

options.text: $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (A_y B_z - A_z B_y) \hat{i} - (A_x B_z - A_z B_x) \hat{j} + (A_x B_y - A_y B_x) \hat{k}$
$\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = A_x B_x \hat{i} + A_y B_y \hat{j} + A_z B_z \hat{k}$

explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (3 \hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} + \hat{k}) \times (\hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}) = 4 \hat{i} - 8 \hat{j} + 4 \hat{k}$.

questionText: If $\vec{A} = 4 \hat{i} - \hat{j} + 2 \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = -2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (4 \hat{i} - \hat{j} + 2 \hat{k}) \times (-2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}) = -7 \hat{i} - 14 \hat{j} - 2 \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: If $\vec{A} = 5 \hat{i} + 2 \hat{j}$ and $\vec{B} = 3 \hat{i} - 4 \hat{j}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (5 \hat{i} + 2 \hat{j}) \times (3 \hat{i} - 4 \hat{j}) = -26 \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the vector product of $\vec{A} = 3 \hat{i}$ and $\vec{B} = 2 \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the cross product rule, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (3 \hat{i}) \times (2 \hat{k}) = -6 \hat{j}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: If $\vec{A} = \hat{i} + \hat{j}$ and $\vec{B} = \hat{j} + \hat{k}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (\hat{i} + \hat{j}) \times (\hat{j} + \hat{k}) = \hat{i} - \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the significance of the cross product in physics?

options.text: It is used to find torque, angular momentum, and magnetic force
It is used to find the magnitude of vectors
It is used to calculate scalar quantities
It is used to determine the sum of vectors

explanation: The cross product is used in physics to find torque, angular momentum, and magnetic force.

questionText: How is the direction of the vector product determined using the right-hand rule?

options.text: Point your fingers in the direction of the first vector and curl them towards the second vector; the thumb points in the direction of the product
Point your fingers in the direction of the second vector and curl them towards the first vector; the thumb points in the direction of the product
Point your fingers in the direction of the first vector and curl them away from the second vector; the thumb points in the direction of the product
Point your fingers in the direction of the second vector and curl them away from the first vector; the thumb points in the direction of the product

explanation: Using the right-hand rule, point your fingers in the direction of the first vector and curl them towards the second vector; the thumb points in the direction of the vector product.

questionText: What is the magnitude of the cross product of two vectors $\vec{A}$ and $\vec{B}$ if they are perpendicular to each other?
explanation: If two vectors $\vec{A}$ and $\vec{B}$ are perpendicular to each other, the magnitude of their cross product is $AB$.

questionText: How does the cross product of two vectors change if the angle between them is $180^\circ$?
explanation: If the angle between two vectors is $180^\circ$, the cross product is zero because $\sin 180^\circ = 0$.

questionText: What is the vector product of $2 \hat{i} - 3 \hat{j} + 4 \hat{k}$ and $\hat{i} + \hat{j} - \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (2 \hat{i} - 3 \hat{j} + 4 \hat{k}) \times (\hat{i} + \hat{j} - \hat{k}) = 7 \hat{i} + 6 \hat{j} + 5 \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: If $\vec{A} = \hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = \hat{i} - \hat{j} - \hat{k}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (\hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}) \times (\hat{i} - \hat{j} - \hat{k}) = 2 \hat{j} - 2 \hat{k}$.

questionText: What is the vector product of $3 \hat{i} - \hat{j}$ and $\hat{j} + 4 \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (3 \hat{i} - \hat{j}) \times (\hat{j} + 4 \hat{k}) = 3 \hat{k} + 12 \hat{i}$.

questionText: What is the vector product of $\vec{A} = 2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} - \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = \hat{i} - 3 \hat{j} + 2 \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} - \hat{k}) \times (\hat{i} - 3 \hat{j} + 2 \hat{k}) = -\hat{i} + 6 \hat{j} - 7 \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the vector product of $\vec{A} = 3 \hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} + \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = \hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (3 \hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} + \hat{k}) \times (\hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}) = 4 \hat{i} - 8 \hat{j} + 4 \hat{k}$.

questionText: What is the cross product of $4 \hat{i} - \hat{j} + 2 \hat{k}$ and $-2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (4 \hat{i} - \hat{j} + 2 \hat{k}) \times (-2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}) = -7 \hat{i} - 14 \hat{j} - 2 \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (\hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}) \times (3 \hat{i} - \hat{j} + \hat{k}) = 7 \hat{i} - 8 \hat{j} + 4 \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the cross product of $\hat{i} - \hat{j} + \hat{k}$ and $\hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (\hat{i} - \hat{j} + \hat{k}) \times (\hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}) = -2 \hat{j}$.

questionText: What is the vector product of $\vec{A} = 2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} - 2 \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j} + \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} - 2 \hat{k}) \times (\hat{i} + 3 \hat{j} + \hat{k}) = 5 \hat{i} - 4 \hat{j} + 5 \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: If $\vec{A} = 3 \hat{i} + \hat{j}$ and $\vec{B} = \hat{i} + 4 \hat{j} + \hat{k}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (3 \hat{i} + \hat{j}) \times (\hat{i} + 4 \hat{j} + \hat{k}) = 3 \hat{k} - \hat{j}$.

questionText: If $\vec{A} = 4 \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j} - \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = 2 \hat{i} - \hat{j} + \hat{k}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (4 \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j} - \hat{k}) \times (2 \hat{i} - \hat{j} + \hat{k}) = 4 \hat{i} - 2 \hat{j} + 14 \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the vector product of $\vec{A} = 2 \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j} + \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = \hat{i} - 4 \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (2 \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j} + \hat{k}) \times (\hat{i} - 4 \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}) = 13 \hat{i} + \hat{j} - 11 \hat{k}$.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion

questionText: What is the cross product of $\vec{A} = \hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = 2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} - \hat{k}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (\hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} + 3 \hat{k}) \times (2 \hat{i} + \hat{j} - \hat{k}) = -5 \hat{i} + 7 \hat{j} - 3 \hat{k}$.

questionText: If $\vec{A} = 2 \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j}$ and $\vec{B} = 4 \hat{i} + 5 \hat{j}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (2 \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j}) \times (4 \hat{i} + 5 \hat{j}) = -7 \hat{k}$.

questionText: If $\vec{A} = 3 \hat{i} + 2 \hat{j}$ and $\vec{B} = \hat{i} + 4 \hat{j}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (3 \hat{i} + 2 \hat{j}) \times (\hat{i} + 4 \hat{j}) = 10 \hat{k}$.

questionText: If $\vec{A} = 2 \hat{i} + 4 \hat{j} - 3 \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = \hat{i} - \hat{j} + 2 \hat{k}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (2 \hat{i} + 4 \hat{j} - 3 \hat{k}) \times (\hat{i} - \hat{j} + 2 \hat{k}) = 5 \hat{i} + 7 \hat{j} + 6 \hat{k}$.

questionText: What is the cross product of $3 \hat{i} - 2 \hat{j}$ and $4 \hat{i} + 5 \hat{j}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (3 \hat{i} - 2 \hat{j}) \times (4 \hat{i} + 5 \hat{j}) = 23 \hat{k}$.

questionText: If $\vec{A} = \hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}$ and $\vec{B} = 2 \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j} + 4 \hat{k}$, what is $\vec{A} \times \vec{B}$?
explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (\hat{i} + \hat{j} + \hat{k}) \times (2 \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j} + 4 \hat{k}) = -\hat{i} + 2 \hat{j} - \hat{k}$.

explanation: Using the determinant method, $\vec{A} \times \vec{B} = (2 \hat{i} + 3 \hat{j}) \times (4 \hat{i} + 5 \hat{j}) = -7 \hat{k}$.

The rate of change of linear displacement

The rate of change of velocity

explanation: The relation between linear velocity ($v$) and angular velocity ($\omega$) is $v = \omega r$, where $r$ is the radius of the circular path.

explanation: The linear velocity of a point on a rotating object is tangential to the circular path.

questionText: How is the centripetal acceleration related to angular velocity?
explanation: The centripetal acceleration ($a_c$) is related to the angular velocity ($\omega$) by the equation $a_c = \omega^2 r$, where $r$ is the radius.

questionText: What is the relationship between angular velocity and the period of rotation?
explanation: The angular velocity ($\omega$) is related to the period of rotation ($T$) by the equation $\omega = \frac{2\pi}{T}$.

questionText: If a particle moves in a circle of radius 2 meters with an angular velocity of 3 rad/s, what is its linear velocity?
explanation: The linear velocity ($v$) is given by $v = \omega r = 3 \times 2 = 6$ m/s.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion
topic: 6.6 Angular Velocity and its Relation with Linear Velocity

questionText: What is the angular velocity of a wheel making 60 revolutions per minute (rpm)?
explanation: The angular velocity ($\omega$) in rad/s is given by $\omega = \frac{2\pi \times 60}{60} = 2\pi$ rad/s.

questionText: How does angular velocity change if the radius of the circular path is halved while keeping the linear velocity constant?

questionText: What is the period of rotation for an object with an angular velocity of $4\pi$ rad/s?
explanation: The period of rotation ($T$) is given by $T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega} = \frac{2\pi}{4\pi} = \frac{1}{2}$ s.

questionText: How is the frequency of rotation related to angular velocity?

questionText: What is the angular velocity of a particle moving in a circle of radius 1 meter with a linear velocity of 10 m/s?

questionText: What is the frequency of rotation for an object with an angular velocity of $6\pi$ rad/s?

questionText: What is the angular velocity of a particle that completes one revolution in 2 seconds?

questionText: What is the centripetal force acting on a 1 kg mass moving in a circle of radius 1 meter at 2 rad/s?

questionText: What is the equation for final angular velocity (ω) in terms of initial angular velocity ($ω_0$), angular acceleration (α), and angular displacement (θ)?

questionText: If a wheel rotates with an angular acceleration of 2 rad/s², how much time will it take to reach an angular velocity of 10 rad/s, starting from rest?
explanation: Using the equation $ω = ω_0 + αt$ with $ω_0 = 0$, $ω = 10$ rad/s, and α = 2 rad/s², we get $10 = 2t$. Solving for t, we get t = 5 seconds.

questionText: If a disk starts from rest and has an angular acceleration of 4 rad/s², what will be its angular velocity after 3 seconds?
explanation: Using the equation $ω = ω_0 + αt$ with $ω_0 = 0$, α = 4 rad/s², and t = 3 seconds, we get $ω = 0 + 4 \times 3 = 12$ rad/s.

questionText: A wheel rotating at 5 rad/s is brought to rest by an angular deceleration of 2 rad/s². How long will it take to stop?
explanation: Using the equation $ω = ω_0 + αt$ with $ω_0 = 5$ rad/s, ω = 0, and α = -2 rad/s², we get $0 = 5 - 2t$. Solving for t, we get t = 2.5 seconds.

topic: 6.10 Kinematics of Rotational Motion about a Fixed Axis

questionText: If a disk accelerates uniformly from rest to an angular velocity of 20 rad/s in 4 seconds, what is its angular acceleration?
explanation: Using the equation $ω = ω_0 + αt$ with $ω_0 = 0$, ω = 20 rad/s, and t = 4 seconds, we get $20 = 0 + α \times 4$. Solving for α, we get α = 5 rad/s².

explanation: Using the equation $ω = ω_0 + αt$ with $ω_0 = 2$ rad/s, α = 3 rad/s², and t = 5 seconds, we get $ω = 2 + 3 \times 5 = 17$ rad/s.

questionText: What is torque?

options.text: A measure of the force that can cause an object to rotate about an axis
A measure of the linear force on an object
A measure of the mass of an object
A measure of the velocity of an object

explanation: Torque is a measure of the force that can cause an object to rotate about an axis.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion
topic: 6.11 Dynamics of Rotational Motion about a Fixed Axis

questionText: What is the SI unit of torque?
explanation: The SI unit of torque is Newton meter (N·m).
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion
topic: 6.11 Dynamics of Rotational Motion about a Fixed Axis

questionText: How is torque (τ) calculated?
explanation: Torque (τ) is calculated using the formula $τ = rF\sin θ$, where $r$ is the distance from the axis of rotation, $F$ is the force, and $θ$ is the angle between the force vector and the lever arm.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion
topic: 6.11 Dynamics of Rotational Motion about a Fixed Axis

questionText: What is the relationship between torque (τ) and angular acceleration (α) for a rigid body?
explanation: The relationship between torque (τ) and angular acceleration (α) for a rigid body is $τ = Iα$, where $I$ is the moment of inertia.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion
topic: 6.11 Dynamics of Rotational Motion about a Fixed Axis

questionText: What is rotational kinetic energy?

options.text: The kinetic energy due to the rotation of an object and is given by $K = \frac{1}{2}Iω^2$
The kinetic energy due to the linear motion of an object
The potential energy due to the height of an object
The total energy of a rotating object

explanation: Rotational kinetic energy is the kinetic energy due to the rotation of an object and is given by $K = \frac{1}{2}Iω^2$, where $I$ is the moment of inertia and $ω$ is the angular velocity.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion
topic: 6.11 Dynamics of Rotational Motion about a Fixed Axis

questionText: What is the work-energy theorem for rotational motion?

options.text: The work done by the net torque on a rotating body is equal to the change in its rotational kinetic energy
The work done by the net force on a rotating body is equal to the change in its linear kinetic energy
The work done by the net torque on a rotating body is equal to the change in its potential energy
The work done by the net force on a rotating body is equal to the change in its rotational kinetic energy

explanation: The work-energy theorem for rotational motion states that the work done by the net torque on a rotating body is equal to the change in its rotational kinetic energy.
chapter: Systems of Particles and Rotational Motion
topic: 6.11 Dynamics of Rotational Motion about a Fixed Axis

questionText: If a rotating body has a moment of inertia of 2 kg·m² and an angular velocity of 3 rad/s, what is its rotational kinetic energy?
explanation: Using the formula for rotational kinetic energy, $K = \frac{1}{2}Iω^2$, with $I = 2$ kg·m² and $ω = 3$ rad/s, we get $K = \frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 3^2 = 9$ J.

questionText: If a rotating body has an initial angular velocity of 4 rad/s and is subjected to a constant angular acceleration of 2 rad/s² for 3 seconds, what is its final angular velocity?
explanation: Using the equation $ω = ω_0 + αt$ with $ω_0 = 4$ rad/s, α = 2 rad/s², and t = 3 seconds, we get $ω = 4 + 2 \times 3 = 10$ rad/s.

questionText: If a torque of 10 N·m is applied to a wheel with a moment of inertia of 2 kg·m², what is the angular acceleration produced?
explanation: Using the relationship $τ = Iα$ with $τ = 10$ N·m and $I = 2$ kg·m², we get $α = τ/I = 10/2 = 5$ rad/s².

questionText: What is the angular momentum (L) of a rotating body with a moment of inertia of 3 kg·m² and an angular velocity of 5 rad/s?
explanation: Using the formula for angular momentum, $L = Iω$, with $I = 3$ kg·m² and $ω = 5$ rad/s, we get $L = 3 \times 5 = 15$ kg·m²/s.

questionText: What is the moment of inertia of a solid disk of mass 4 kg and radius 0.5 m about an axis through its center and perpendicular to its plane?
explanation: The moment of inertia of a solid disk about an axis through its center and perpendicular to its plane is given by $I = \frac{1}{2}mr^2$. With $m = 4$ kg and $r = 0.5$ m, we get $I = \frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times (0.5)^2 = 0.5$ kg·m².

questionText: What is the work done by a torque of 6 N·m applied through an angle of $\frac{π}{3}$ radians?

questionText: If a torque of 25 N·m is applied to a wheel with a moment of inertia of 5 kg·m², what is the angular acceleration produced?
explanation: Using the relationship $τ = Iα$ with $τ = 25$ N·m and $I = 5$ kg·m², we get $α = τ/I = 25/5 = 5$ rad/s².

questionText: A solid sphere of mass 4 kg and radius 0.2 m is rotating with an angular velocity of 5 rad/s. What is its rotational kinetic energy?
explanation: Using the formula for rotational kinetic energy, $K = \frac{1}{2}Iω^2$, with $I = \frac{2}{5}mr^2 = \frac{2}{5} \times 4 \times (0.2)^2 = 0.032$ kg·m² and $ω = 5$ rad/s, we get $K = \frac{1}{2} \times 0.032 \times 5^2 = 0.4$ J.

questionText: What is angular momentum?

options.text: The product of a body's rotational inertia and rotational velocity about a particular axis
The rate of change of angular displacement
The rate of change of linear velocity
The product of mass and radius

explanation: Angular momentum is the product of a body's rotational inertia and rotational velocity about a particular axis.

questionText: What is the SI unit of angular momentum?
explanation: The SI unit of angular momentum is kilogram meter squared per second (kg·m²/s).

questionText: How is angular momentum (L) calculated?
explanation: Angular momentum (L) is calculated using the formula $L = Iω$, where $I$ is the moment of inertia and $ω$ is the angular velocity.

questionText: What is the relationship between torque (τ) and the rate of change of angular momentum (dL/dt)?

questionText: What is the principle of conservation of angular momentum?

options.text: If no external torque acts on a system, the total angular momentum of the system remains constant
If no external force acts on a system, the total linear momentum of the system remains constant
If no external torque acts on a system, the total kinetic energy of the system remains constant
If no external force acts on a system, the total potential energy of the system remains constant

explanation: The principle of conservation of angular momentum states that if no external torque acts on a system, the total angular momentum of the system remains constant.

questionText: A wheel with a moment of inertia of 8 kg·m² is rotating at 3 rad/s. What is its angular momentum?
explanation: Using the formula for angular momentum, $L = I \omega$, with $I = 8 \text{ kg} \cdot \text{m}^2$ and $\omega = 3 \text{ rad/s}$, we get $L = 8 \times 3 = 24 \text{ kg} \cdot \text{m}^2/\text{s}$.

questionText: What happens to the angular momentum of a rotating system if the moment of inertia is halved and the angular velocity is doubled?
explanation: If the moment of inertia of a rotating system is halved and the angular velocity is doubled, the angular momentum remains constant.

topic: 6.12 Angular Momentum in Case of Rotations about a Fixed Axis

questionText: What is the angular momentum of a solid sphere of mass 10 kg and radius 0.15 m rotating with an angular velocity of 7 rad/s?
explanation: Using the formula for angular momentum, $L = I \omega$, with $I = \frac{2}{5}mr^2 = \frac{2}{5} \times 10 \times (0.15)^2 = 0.018 \text{ kg} \cdot \text{m}^2$ and $\omega = 7 \text{ rad/s}$, we get $L = 0.018 \times 7 = 0.126 \text{ kg} \cdot \text{m}^2/\text{s}$.

questionText: If a rotating body has a moment of inertia of 12 kg·m² and an angular velocity of 2 rad/s, what is its angular momentum?
explanation: Using the formula for angular momentum, $L = I \omega$, with $I = 12 \text{ kg} \cdot \text{m}^2$ and $\omega = 2 \text{ rad/s}$, we get $L = 12 \times 2 = 24 \text{ kg} \cdot \text{m}^2/\text{s}$.
